results.headline: Celebrity Journalism as Contact Sport
results.summary_short: Vaporous and chilled to freezing, “Interview” lacks a single honest moment, but it does have plenty of diverting ones.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Interview

results.headline: Finding a New Calling in Grass Skirts
results.summary_short: “Hula Girls” is the latest entry in a durable subgenre about marginalized eccentrics who learn a new skill and become better, stronger people.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hula Girls

results.headline: The Friendless François Rides the Taxi of Life
results.summary_short: “My Best Friend” is a sweet, sentimental tale of a kind that would be insufferably maudlin if made in Hollywood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Best Friend

results.headline: Back in Iraq, Unearthing Old and New
results.summary_short: With “Nice Bombs,” Usama Alshaibi, a Chicago-based filmmaker, adds his noncommittal voice and unsteady camera to the Iraq conversation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nice Bombs

results.headline: Sex, Shouting and Temptation Once Upon Today in Acapulco
results.summary_short: “Drama/Mex” means to say something about its country of origin, though it’s hard to know exactly what.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drama/Mex

results.headline: Hogwarts Under Siege
results.summary_short: The latest Harry Potter movie begins with a spot of unpleasantness at the Dursleys and ends with Harry facing down Lord Voldemort.
results.display_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

results.headline: The Weird Sisters Prophesy Blood From a Dance Floor
results.summary_short: Geoffrey Wright’s brutal and thrilling new version of “Macbeth” envisions the thane of Cawdor as a longhaired, drug-addled gangster.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Macbeth

results.headline: Big Teenage Dreams, Small-Town Doldrums
results.summary_short: An itty-bitty movie with a great big heart, “Colma: The Musical” is about how we learn to give voice — joyfully, honestly, loudly — to the truest parts of ourselves.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Colma: The Musical

results.headline: Private Solders for Hire
results.summary_short: There isn’t as much exposé as you might expect in “Shadow Company,” but there’s considerably more thoughtfulness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shadow Company

results.headline: The Toughest Job Interview Ever
results.summary_short: “The Method” is a funny film that touches on a corporation’s responsibility to society, the price of ambition and the persistence of workplace sexism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Method

results.headline: Biomechanical Erotica
results.summary_short: “De Lama Lamina” is a record of a huge performance art collaboration between Matthew Barney and the musician Arto Lindsay.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of De Lama Lamina

results.headline: He’s a Very Good Pianist, but He’s a Very Bad Boy
results.summary_short: Uneasily straddling age groups and genres, “Joshua” is a highly effective family drama cloaked in the stale tropes of the demon-seed thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joshua

results.headline: Fights With a Bang
results.summary_short: “Dynamite Warrior” is a genre confection with more than a passing resemblance to Hong Kong martial arts movies of the 1980s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dynamite Warrior

results.headline: Talking About Her Issues, Taking Them on the Road
results.summary_short: By turns playful, sexy, tragic and contemplative, “Flying” is an addictive soap about sexuality and sisterhood.
results.display_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman

results.headline: A Vietnam P.O.W. Story, Tangling With the Vines of Convention
results.summary_short: “Rescue Dawn” is a satisfying genre picture that challenges the viewer’s expectations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rescue Dawn

results.headline: Ready to Put This Union Asunder
results.summary_short: If the beloved with whom you see “License to Wed” can’t stop talking about how great it was, you might want to cancel the nuptials.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of License to Wed

results.headline: Car Wars With Shape-Shifters ‘R’ Us
results.summary_short: Boys and their toys are in full formation in “Transformers,” a movie of epically assaultive noise and nonsense.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers

results.headline: Voilà! A Rat for All Seasonings
results.summary_short: Displaying the usual meticulousness associated with the Pixar brand, “Ratatouille” is a nearly flawless piece of popular art.

results.headline: Over the World’s Infinite Noise, Five Friends Sing Their Songs
results.summary_short: “Falling” is at once a character study times five and something of a generational snapshot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Falling

results.headline: Sustained in Death by the Memory of One Great Love
results.summary_short: At first, second and final glance, Susan Minot’s “Evening” doesn’t seem as if it would translate easily to the big screen. It hasn’t.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evening
